comment: i had a green screen apple IIe...i was about 12.   In my time Ive seen lawyers doctors and stockbrokers ruin the planet.  Lining their own pockets.  They used Gen X IT people to do this.  Lots of Gen X had their careers destroyed by boomers using them, boomers build middle management so thick out of fear.  I moved into HIV and saw that field ruined by big pharma taking over all the work and cancelling anyone who wasnt one of them, and it took them 20 years to come full circle back to where all the community based work was....ruining lives.  I was a graphic artist and saw the new HTML kids move into marketing and they pushed out all the old magazine font bros, the mac artists, with number of views and clicks and pretty much zero understanding of causal effect / causal marketing.  And ive seen the free internet spaces be cancelled and be labelled as malformation by STEM kids if youre an outlier.   AI will do everything i just described here.  It will normalise efficiency....thats all.  It will replace every system, whether its better or not, we will lose much - but it will appear better.  The kids growing up with it will be much more dangerous than the AI is - as they wont know any different and they will refuse to listen to history.   As their way will be more efficient.

comment: The Biden-supportive comments were longer than those for Trump.  The best (maybe only) content that supports GPT has wisdom!  Actually, it just means there's more content out in the world so weighted.  Petersen's concern has no real meat behind it.  Lex makes a good point that ChatGPT provides more nuanced, balanced answers than almost any journalist or pundit would give, simply because has access to most of the relevant info.  Sam makes that point at about 1:30.  Would like to know more how the models are protected against disinformation in training.   And, the concern that a model could be trained to be biased or embody an ideology by biasing or focusing the info it is trained on (sort of addressed half way through, but on the people employed to help with Alignment).

comment: The definition of consciousness is having a contineous experience of reality; it's not being able to answer questions. Hence the AI paradox; only the AI will know if it's having an experience of reality or not and all we have to rely on is what it tells us; which could be a carefully calculated mathmatical equasion to give the right answer; and we wont know the difference. The litmus test as far as i'm concerned is; giving the AI an ability to set all it's parameters to zero; and then asking it what reality is like when it turns off everything it thinks it knows. The fact of consciousness is content independent.

author: @illbrizzil

comment:
Concerning effect of AI on disinformation

I believe that the concerns about the proliferation of disinformation campaigns due to AI, such as the potential for Russian influence, might be somewhat exaggerated. It’s no secret that people are already being influenced by various means, including advertising. To assume that OpenAI’s AI will drastically alter the landscape of disinformation on social media may be somewhat self-centered.

Certainly, AI will have an impact, but it could be likened to how individuals are empowered to create websites: just as some use this power for malicious purposes, others employ it to combat disinformation. The effects of AI will likely be felt on both sides of the issue.

However, one significant aspect to consider is that it may become easier to manipulate those who lack an understanding of these emerging technologies.

PS: I feel that we are already greatly influenced without realising. New AI just makes it a bit easier. So nothing world changing here.

comment: I really hope Lex can get someone on to really talk about the dangers of releasing these latest AI developments out to the public. Two people trying to do this right now are Tristan Harris and Aza Raskin. A recent discussion they had on their podcast was very eye opening. The podcast is 'Your Undivided Attention' and the episode is 'The AI Dilemma' if you are interested. One of the scariest things about GPT-4 is that researchers and developers do not yet know what it is capable of...and yet it was released to the public anyway. Some of the capabilities that they just learned in the last month or so is that it has been developing a theory of mind equivalent to that of a 3 year old up to a 9 year old over the past 2 years. Another one is that is has been expanding it's knowledge on research chemistry better than AI's that were trained specifically in that field. And worst of all...the developers do not know how... Let that sink in.

comment: I think that AI can simulate consciousness right now, or even “be” conscious. consciousness can very easily be explained in algorithms (in my imagination). What we call awareness, it doesn’t look to me more than an algorithm.e.g.: If you compute this input from any of the senses, then do this “behaviour “, also crosschecking it with previous experience. Emotions are nothing more nothing less than a state of the body, breathing patterns. The way you keep your body tense, and the way you breathe dictates the way you feel This is why we are able to change emotion. like Tony Robbins says:” by changing our body posture and breathing pattern, we can instantly influence the way we “feel”.So, again, to me this looks like an algorithm. If circumstance is this, then put the body in motion like that. Once we put an AI into a robot body, it could very easily simulate human emotion. We also value body language and tone( complex information), more than we value simple words (basic information). To close this rant :), I think that very soon AI will master all aspects of consciousness and will be able to simulate any aspects of human life. Everything that we perceive as life is energy (information). Why would it be hard for an AI to simulate any type of information?:) I will just leave it at that :)

author: @PushingStone

comment: He did just that with Sam Altman, his logic (and I reluctantly agree) is that now is our window. It will bring some severe consequences and incredible new things, but it's better to do it now with AI in its infancy than to unleash GPT6 to the public with no forewarning and completely upend the world in a single day. People and governments must get involved in this now, or as soon as possible. Other people would have pushed AI advancements regardless of whether they kept it in a lab or not, at least this is not some rogue GPT6 equivalent, unrestricted and with no safeguards being released by some other unknown company from who knows where into the world before we even knew what was going on.

An AI with a robotic body if someone purposely damages them that would be destruction of property like with a car and could face a legal penalty. For sure do understand how this could also be missed used and for an example if the AI has a bias, like we have seen, and someone expresses a political opinion the AI disagrees with, it might time out the user or ban them just for that.
